repnme.cdata!: Guatemala - Second Social Investment Fund Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings convey a satisfactory project
            outcome, likely sustainability, and substantial
            institutional development impacts. The rapid response by
            Social Investment Fund or FIS, and the Bank to the damage
            caused by Hurricane Mitch onto transportation
            infrastructure, showed the effective role social funds play
            in emergency situations, due to their unique design and
            procedures, able in addition, to invest in community
            infrastructure, fostering employment opportunities. Specific
            to the project experience, lessons convey the FIS was one of
            the better-rated institutions in the country regarding the
            effectiveness of poverty targeting. However, FIS lacks
            adequate coordination with other funds, and particularly
            with line ministries. Because FIS has traditionally focused
            on the provision of basic infrastructure, it would be
            beneficial to increase investments in training and
            strengthening community organizations, with investments
            related to income generation activities, in some promising
            areas such as agro-forestry. It is important to note that,
            while one of the main indicators used by Bank management,
            was the level of disbursement, as learned in this project
            (and even being a high performing project), attention should
            be paid to under-performing aspects, for although financing
            may not be large, may well have the potential to enhance
            subproject sustainability.

repnme.cdata!: Guatemala - Second Social Investment Fund Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Social Investment Fund (FIS)
            Project seeks to: a) support the Government's poverty
            alleviation efforts by targeting its investments to the
            poorest areas and population groups; b) contribute to
            participatory decision-making by strengthening the capacity
            of community-based organizations and local governments to
            define problems, prioritize needs, plan and implement
            small-scale community-based subprojects; and c) ensure
            sustainability by developing adequate arrangements for
            subproject operations and maintenance. The project consists
            of three components. First, community-based subprojects will
            support pre-investment feasibility studies for small-scale
            infrastructure and services subprojects, such as schools,
            health posts, water supply, sanitation and latrine systems,
            bridges, and cultural heritage. Second, community training
            will provide training for beneficiaries, and local staff of
            line ministries and municipalities. Third, institutional
            development will support consultancies to promote
            participatory planning, women's participation in FIS
            subprojects. It will also finance the decentralization of
            the FIS operation.
